sentences.sentence: If there is anything positive from Kanye West's anti-Jewish screeds last fall, it is perhaps that more people are now aware of both fringe and mainstream actors who, with the support of social media platforms, are promoting anti-Jewish racism.

This is a hatred that, for thousands of years, has seesawed between the fringe and the mainstream - much like a dormant virus reawakened periodically in a compromised immune system.Although these attempts to normalize Jew-hatred are nothing new, what is novel is that these ideologies, which once took months - or even years - to manifest, now spread with a single click.Jews were accused of causing the Black Death in the 14th century, blamed for socioeconomic calamities in early 20th-century Russia and scapegoated for Germany's defeat following the First World War.
Historically, when Jew-hate goes viral, violence follows.

It is therefore more critical than ever to pay attention to today's fast-spreading social media trends.In 2018, the Network Contagion Research Institute (NCRI) published a peer-reviewed study quantifying an escalation in antisemitic memes and rhetoric on sites like 4chan and Gab.
The report noted a "worrying trend of real-world action mirroring online rhetoric.

"Weeks later, we saw a manifestation of this when, only moments after posting a reference to an antisemitic conspiracy theory on Gab, an individual entered the Tree of Life Synagogue in Pittsburgh during Saturday Sabbath morning services, murdering 11 innocent Jewish worshippers and injuring six more in the deadliest attack on Jews in United States history.

A subsequent NCRI analysis highlighted the assailant's deep entrenchment in online antisemitism.The recent surge in online antisemitism, particularly as it relates to Kanye West, has sparked several real-world incidents of violence and hate: in Los Angeles, a group brandished a banner reading "Kanye is right" over a freeway; a Jewish cemetery in Illinois was vandalized with graffiti referencing West; and a Jewish man was assaulted in New York's Central Park by an attacker yelling "Kanye 2024.
"West also defended basketball player Kyrie Irving's promotion of a film that accuses Jews of having run the trans-Atlantic slave trade.
Weeks later, New York police officers arrested two young men entering Penn Station who had made credible threats against synagogues.
Police later recovered a firearm, knife and Nazi paraphernalia.
Hours before his arrest, one of the suspects tweeted, "Jews owned the ships.
"This is not just an American phenomenon, as similar trends have emerged in Canada.During the May 2021 Gaza-Israel war, online hate spilled onto the streets.

In Montreal, following an anti-Israel rally hosted and promoted by groups active in spreading online hate, two young men were arrested after driving through a Jewish neighbourhood yelling slurs and threatening Jews.

The suspects, who posted their actions on TikTok, were charged(https://www.cija.ca/individual_behind_may_2021_threats_to_montreal_jewish_community_sentenced) with uttering threats and possession of a weapon for a dangerous purpose, and one received an additional charge of wilful promotion of hatred.Another Canadian example is the disturbing case of Laith Marouf, who has become infamous across the country for such virulent, hate-filled tweets as, "I have a motto: Life is too short for shoes with laces, or for entertaining Jewish White Supremacists with anything but a bullet to the head.
"And: "Every book Jewish White Supremacists, the heirs of the Nazis, destroy, burn, and ban; we will rewrite with our blood, and republish with our sweat.
By the name of the Creator; there will be not one Zionist left on our land, not even a footprint, after the promised Liberation.
"Data gathered by NCRI show that, in May 2021, Marouf issued more than 1,000 tweets, the majority of which, while garnering likes and retweets, promoted hate.
Before Twitter eventually shut down his account for violating its hateful conduct policy, Marouf had gained 2,219 followers.

Similarly, in the hours after he tweeted his vow to go "death con 3 On JEWISH PEOPLE," West's rate of follower growth doubled.Online hate not only hurts its victims directly but also serves as a predictor of potential real-world violence.

Real-time monitoring can act as an early warning system, alerting a vulnerable community to the possible threat of harm.It is not enough merely to track online hate, however - it must be pulled up by its roots.
Education at all levels of society about antisemitism, radicalization and online hate is essential.

Combined with vigilant monitoring, education can act as a vaccine against the viral antisemitism on social media and create safer communities both online and off.National PostAlex Goldenberg is the lead intelligence analyst and a research fellow at the Network Contagion Research Institute Rutgers Miller Center for Community Protection and Resilience.

Becca Wertman-Traub is the director of research at the Centre for Israel and Jewish Affairs, the advocacy agent of Jewish federations across Canada.Avi Benlolo: The backlash against Kanye West's antisemitism should now be directed at the UN(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/avi-benlolo-the-backlash-against-kanye-wests-antisemitism-should-now-be-directed-at-the-un)NP View: The insidious silence from non-Jews about Kanye's and Marouf's antisemitism(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/np-view-speaking-out-against-kanye-west-and-antisemitism-in-general-should-not-be-a-partisan-issue) !
